author: mklement0
body:
## Summary of the new feature/enhancement

When a path (typically a _file-system_ path) is provided as input, it is helpful to know the _form_ of that path, with respect to whether:

* it is relative (`./foo` or `foo`)
* it is absolute (`c:\foo` on Windows, `/foo` on Unix)
* it is rooted (`\foo`, `/foo`) - note: only on Unix-like platforms is a _rooted_ path also _absolute_
* it is a UNC path (`\\server\share\foo`)

To that end we could introduce an enumeration-based `-PathForm` (aliased to `-Form`)  parameter that complements the existing `-PathType` (`-Type`) parameter (which examines the type of the item being referred to - container vs. leaf).

```powershell
# WISHFUL THINKING

PS> Test-Path foo -Form Relative   # ditto for ./foo
True

PS> Test-Path /foo -Form Rooted
True

PS> Test-Path C:\foo -Form Absolute
True

PS> Test-Path \\server\share\foo -Form Unc
True
```

Note that this would obviate the need for `Split-Path`'s awkward `-IsAbsolute` switch - a switch that is poor fit for that cmdlet.
title: Add a -PathForm (-Form) parameter to Test-Path, to allow testing for whether a path is rooted, absolute, relative, or an UNC path.
